review:
It's a free VR adventure where you solve few simple environmental puzzles within the time limit. Hard to believe that it was a payed product since it's too short even for a tech demo.

There is no inventory: most key items just disappear upon pick up and then used automatically. That makes already easy puzzles even easier. Hand interactions are clunky because in-game hands are not aligned with controllers properly. 

Environments look nice thanks to fog effects and dark shadows. This and good ambient sounds make the game quite atmospheric and overall worth playing, despite its flaws.

The game works fine on Reverb G2.

review:
Storm VR is a free VR survival game.  It worked on my system, looked ok, played ok, sounded ok.  This is a quick game, you only have a few minutes to live, up to 14.  You will have to play this game several times to get the lay of the land, memorize where everything you need is at, plan a good route, and carry through with your plan.  Has 5 steam achievements that are doable within the time it takes to win.  You have a choice of language, English or Chinese.  This was at one time a paid product, now is free to play.  The voice over is English and understandable.  The teleport beam shoots straight out rather than in an arc like it should, which makes the bumpy hilly terrain difficult to navigate.  Your virtual hands are weirdly positioned, making the code plate hard to work. 
  
 [spoiler] The car tag plate changes each run.  After you win you get a trailer of what the dev is maybe making next.  [/spoiler]  
  
Try this, if you like survival games.

I love deserts and barren, frozen wastelands, so this was right up my alley. I appreciate that you don't get everything all at one. At first I thought I was experiencing two seperate games, but then both parts came together (beautifully) and wove together a really fun experience. I'm not kidding when I say I had sweat pouring from my face. (Did I mention I hate timers?) Absolutely loved this experience- and the periodic voice narration is pleasant too. A+ in all areas. Can't wait for more!

TLDR: Loved this immensely, and I'd gladly pay more. Great fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044983093', 'num_games_owned': 2355, 'num_reviews': 204, 'playtime_forever': 22, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1518957881}
review:
[h1]Keep in mind the playtime is about 10 minutes.[/h1]

You're plonked down in the middle of a snowstorm and tasked with finding shelter and warmth. Your time is running out and your temperature is dropping (the UI is on your wristwatch, which is good). You can barely see ahead of you. Each teleport jump eats away at your time depending on how far you jump - a clever game mechanic that I appreciate.

Find your way through the blizzard, make sure you find everything you need, and perform tasks in the right order and within the time limit in order to make it to safety and survive.

The voice acting and the UI are great.

When you finish it, you get a peek at the larger game that's being planned, and a video trailer that's pretty cool actually.

Cons:
I don't like the constant heartbeat sound - I can't stand games that do that.
Also the teleport beam shoots straight out rather than in an arc like it should, which makes the bumpy hilly terrain difficult to navigate.
Your virtual hands are weirdly positioned. Not a big deal but it's a bit jarring.

Not sure how I feel about it having a price. It's basically a demo and very short. But I enjoyed playing it, so I don't mind so much.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049701098', 'num_games_owned': 3699, 'num_reviews': 832, 'playtime_forever': 29, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1517109526}
review:
[h1]Played On: [b]HTC Vive[/b][/h1]

Storm VR is an atmospheric puzzle game that is set in the middle of nowhere, in the midst of a snowstorm. Players are tasked with finding shelter in order to survive the frostbite inducing -30C temperatures, all the while having little visibility as a windy winter storm rages around them. The adventure is short, clocking in at around 8 minutes when completing the scenario flawlessly. However, learning the puzzles well enough to reach the end will push the longevity of the title up to about half an hour.

The very first playthrough is almost a guaranteed failure, Storm VR is built for trial-and-error repetition; learning from previous mistakes so that on the next attempt one is able to progress more quickly through the previous puzzles. While many gamers, including myself, are lost at the very beginning, it soon becomes clear that there are only three landmarks worth visiting, though it does take some effort to find them due to the obscured visibility. Speed is a key factor during gameplay, and the in-game watch ticks away the seconds of life that players have left; death via hypothermia and frost-bite are always imminent.

Locomotion is always a make-or-break for potential buyers, and many may be disheartened to hear that the only available movement type is teleportation. Each teleport takes away anywhere from 1-3 seconds from the in-game timer, so calculating the moves to complete the puzzle is another factor to consider. The graphics are decent, at least as far as anyone can tell due to the unrelenting snowstorm. The most impressive thing is that the closer to death one becomes, the in-game hands become more red, and slowly more black from frostbite.

Storm VR is a small part of a larger picture that has yet to be unveiled; at the very end, the game alludes to the fact that this release is merely one small part of an episodic adventure. Although a large portion of the gameplay is trial-and-error, Storm VR is a very enjoyable timed puzzle game if one has the patience for that kind of thing. The minimal visibility creates a more hefty challenge as well. For the small price of $2.19 CAD, it's a half-hour well spent. However, it's still uncertain if the remainder of the game is being worked on, and if it will ever be released; the developer isn't very active or timely in answering questions in the forums.

[h1]Rating: [b]3.0/5.0[/b] - Average, can take it or leave it.[/h1]

review:
Storm VR is an episodic puzzle title, that features roughly 15-30 minutes of gameplay (your mileage may vary). This title is set in an outdoor venue that's having a wild storm, and your objective is to survive. There are a couple of fetch quests and light puzzles around, and the actions are executed by motions too.

In this game, your gameplay is constraint by a rather short time limit, and its easy to die as a result. Every time you play however, you learn more about the game and the solutions, thus increase your chance of survival in subsequent attempt (it took me 3 tries to finally clear it).

The game is rather atmospheric, and the increasingly fast beeping sound on the watch really makes you feel anxious, if you haven't felt so from the storms around you. You move by teleportation, and you really have to make use of your surroundings to make sure you are not lost from the storm. That and couple with the awesome voice acting, really heighten the tension of the game.

The price tag fits the game time well enough. If you are looking for a bit size title, you should consider it. This is just a prelude to bigger things to come (there will be more episode according to the developer).

review:
You enter a snowy and stormy environment and you have to survive. In order to do so, you have to solve a couple of puzzles.  

Let's start with the price. Only $1.99. So the price corresponds well with the amount of play you get. Somewhere the developers need to put food on the table just like everyone else. We feel the price tag is well deserved. You get roughly 10 minutes of gameplay. This actually makes the game only playable once. Because, when you have figured out the puzzles, how to survive, you probably won't play the game again.

But that is probably the developers thought: to be a one time experience, so with that said, 2 dollars is worth it. It shouldn't be more. So this game is great for new players or maybe letting others try it out to get a nice VR experience.

The graphics and the gameplay was fine to. You teleport like most games and interact with objects. And the object interactions were good. We don't want to spoil anything here. 

Summary: Worth the price, a game you play once (if you don't die ofc), good for beginners or letting others try who haven't played the game before. It's not really a group game because once you know the solution it's over. But we believe this is the developers thought, and it makes sense. We are pretty sure this is more of a taste of what's coming, more developed puzzles. 

And the idea of fightning against time is a great stress factor! 

Watch us play it here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4uXPjJWeHzg

review:
Storm VR is a survival game in which the player faces a snowstorm in this first episode, ‘Snowstorm’. Another episodic experience in VR but not at all predictable. Somehow it manages to strike the perfect balance between giving the player the unique cinematic experience that only VR can offer, whilst simultaneously involving the player so that they feel like an active participant AT ALL TIMES in the game, as opposed to an onlooker watching a film. Made by a small team, it really is spectacular for what it offers. STORM VR is just the first episode of what looks set to be an exciting series, and leaves you on the edge of your seat wanting more.

review:
The Storm VR is very short and very... small.
The immersion is not that great and for some reason the performance also hasn't been the best.
I think I was running into reprojection since the controllers were not super smooth. (OCed GTX1070.)
It is just a few ugly trees, a low detail car/house, very low view distance and a few snowflakes.
It really isn't that much more. Should have been a free demo but of course I gladly paid the developers for the effort,
hoping more would follow. But since purchase, nothing has changed.
However the Storm VR has just been updated... with Oculus Rift touch support. Like this was something we waiting customers were waiting for..  It looks like the developers are happy with how Storm VR turned out and they are working on the next title. In my opinion there are quite a lot of things to improve and fix in Storm VR. Or even expand it just a LITTLE, in appreciation to the people who have already bought their experience. But no...

Simply impossible to recommend this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089911040', 'num_games_owned': 743, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 108, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 108, 'last_played': 1474951297}
review:
Storm 这个游戏上线 Steam 似乎有点晚了，从去年十月发布demo以来，等了差不多一年了。

我真希望他们去除现在这个简单的章节，后面的内容会变得越来越丰富。大体上不要让喜欢这类 VR 冒险解密游戏的玩家失望。

——————————————————————————————————————

相较于UNIT9在去年十月发布的 Oculus DK2 版的 DEMO ，这个全新的DEMO似乎除了剧情的进步，其他内容甚至变少了。

当时的版本有三种解救自己的办法，现在被浓缩成了一种，而且并不复杂，正常情况二十分钟解决战斗。

我个人觉得，游戏画质较之于去年的DEMO版甚至是有退步的。DEMO 版给人的恐怖感，现在也被削弱了。

目前的版本，结合了 HTC Vive 的手势控制器，利用瞬移来作为行动方式，

让目前的这个章节显得尤为尴尬！一款冒险生存游戏，尽然少了移动方式上的紧迫感，游戏体验就变得不那么好了。

游戏中，遇到时间紧急的时候，只要狂按传送键就好了，所以在冰雪中跋涉的紧张感，求生的压迫感非常弱。

《Amigdala》里面有一段经过格林兰雪地的初始章节，那种一步一个脚印走在雪地上的沙沙声响，我现在依旧记得清晰。

而Storm中的这种声音与瞬移的感觉也不对，与主角无尽的碎碎念更是显得格格不入，

漫天风雪，能见度太低似乎就不需要BB了，想办法好好活下去就对了。

很多时候，游戏开发者没有将手柄的支持加入到 VR 游戏里，恰恰是一种武断的做法，HTC Vive并不一定要用手势控制器。

懂 VR，而不懂游戏，也有可能让 VR 游戏没有想象中那么好。

希望，之后的游戏弄够在游戏操作上加入原来游戏手柄的适配，让这款游戏的体验更好，

或者用其他的更好的移动方式来代替。又或者Oculus版本与Vive版的体验会截然不同？

游戏的卖价15块，虽然就demo而言，价格看似比较合理。

但是我仍旧对UNIT9很失望，一年过去了，你就给我看这个？！

——————————————————————

最后，有什么建议和意见请留言告知，我们下一个VR游戏的评测界面见。

review:
如果你对这个游戏感兴趣，不妨先看看我的视频(video):
http://v.youku.com/v_show/id_XMTczODcyMDQyOA==.html

首先这居然是一个解谜类游戏，我挺意外的，不过在暴风雪中解谜别有一番味道
手冻的很有感觉，只是我觉得现在还太短，如果能长一点就好了
在游戏中，玩家得面对残酷的暴风雪，用5分钟的时间去找到避难屋。随时间流逝，玩家所操纵的角色会渐渐被暴风雪侵蚀，从而身体会慢慢被冻僵，行动越发缓慢
想象一下你正身处于漫天冰雪，白茫茫一片。你手脚都被冻僵了，只能艰难的前行。往哪里走呢，辨不清方向，只能走一步算一步。你一边走一边思考着人生，或许你的生命就这样结束，都没人能找你的遗体，于是心里又充满了恐惧与深深地绝望。就在你快要精疲力尽的时候，前方突然出现了两间屋子，和一辆被雪覆盖的汽车。屋子里有灯光，汽车似乎需要什么就能发动......这大概就是《Storm》的故事背景。

希望后续有更好玩的关卡！加油

我喜欢玩VR也喜欢探索最新的VR游戏，也会用心做好每一个视频
steam是一个要花钱的平台，所以我希望用我的视频让大家能更好的了解每一个游戏
最后，祝大家游戏越快哦~

author: {'steamid': '76561197966401809', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 917, 'playtime_forever': 15, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1474719695}
review:
Eine sehr coole VR Erfahrung, bei der man unter Zeitdruck einem Schneesturm entkommen muss und ein warmes Plätzchen finden muss. Wir müssen Gegenstände kombinieren und kleine Rätsel lösen.
Das Spiel ist ultra kurz (wenn man es beim ersten Versuch schafft, 5 Minuten).
Was mich etwas gestört hat, ist der Protagonist, der permanent und wie ein Wasserfall labert.
Klar, das soll darstellen, dass er bemüht ist, zu überleben und durch Reden gegen die Kälte ankommen will, aber man muss bedenken, dass man selber total unter Zeitdruck ist und nachdenken muss, wie es weitergeht und da kann man sich erstens nicht drauf konzentrieren, was er da die ganze Zeit sagt und zweitens lenkt einen das auch unglaublich ab. 
Es mag so gewollt sein, aber mich hat es genervt.
Ich empfehle das Spiel trotzdem weiter, es hat echt Spaß gemacht und für 3 Dollar kann man nicht viel falsch machen!

[u]Positive Merkmale:[/u]
[list]
    	[*] Schöne Grafik für VR Verhältnisse
    	[*] Tolle Atmosphäre, auch wegen den guten Soundeffekten, man fühlt sich wie im Schneesturm
	[*] Story schein interessant zu werden, wir wissen nicht wie wir dorthin gekommen sind, aber alles soll zusammenhängen
	[*] Steuerung funktioniert ohne Probleme
	[*] Keine Motion-Sickness wegen Teleportation
[/list]

[u]Negative Merkmale:[/u]
[list]
	[*] Nerviger Protagonist, er blubbert am laufenden Band wie ein Wasserfall ohne Unterbrechung
	[*] ULTRA kurz (5min!) wenn man es beim ersten Versuch schafft (ich hatte ca. 10min mit zwei Versuchen)
[/list]
